facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 18 of 1952 filed in Supreme Court with special leave.

facts.text: No dispute as to the facts material for the purposes of this appeal.

facts.text: Board of Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay auctioned plots Nos. 16, 17 and 18 around April 15, 1908.

anchor.surface_text: or about April 15, 1908, the Board of Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay put up to auction plots Nos. 16, 17 and 18

facts.text: Sitaram Luxman was the highest bidder at auction and declared tenant at annual rent of 4.5% of Rs. 29 per sq yard.

anchor.surface_text: One Sitaram Luxman was the highest bidder and was declared the tenant at an annual rent per square yard to be calculated at the rate of 41/2 per cent of Rs. 29

facts.text: Sitaram Luxman signed memorandum of agreement and entered possession after deposit.

anchor.surface_text: he signed the memorandum of agreement incorporating the companyditions upon which the auction was held and by which he agreed to be bound. He deposited the moneys

facts.text: Sitaram Luxman agreed to build a 5-floor building costing at least Rs. 50,000.

anchor.surface_text: By clause 7 Sitaram Luxman agreed, within the time specified therein, to build and companyplete at a companyt of number less than Rs. 50,000 a building companysisting of 5 floors

facts.text: Lease granted on April 19, 1916 by Trustees to Rustomji Dhunjibhoy Sethna, receiver in Suit No. 720 of 1913, for 999 years from April 15, 1908.

anchor.surface_text: the companypletion of the building, by an Indenture -of lease made April 19, 1916, between, the Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay and one Rustomji Dhunjibhoy Sethna the receiver

facts.text: Lease rent: Re. 1 up to Jan 15, 1909, then Rs. 2,916 yearly.

anchor.surface_text: paying therefor up to January, 15, 1909, the rent of Re. I and during the remainder of the term the yearly rent of Rs. 2,916 by equal quarterly payments.

facts.text: In 1925, properties of Trustees vested in Bombay Municipality by Bombay Act XVI of 1925.

anchor.surface_text: In 1925 all the properties of the Trustees for the Improvement of the City of Bombay vested in the Bombay Municipality under and by virtue of Bombay Act XVI of 1925.

facts.text: Shri Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Limited acquired lessee's interest by deed of assignment dated April 26, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed of assignment made April 26, 1948, Shri Bhatia Co-operative Housing Society Limited, a society registered under the Bombay Co-operative Societies Act,

facts.text: Appellant served notice to respondent on June 29, 1948 to vacate Block No. B/2 by July 31, 1948; respondent monthly tenant at Rs. 52-5-9.

anchor.surface_text: June 29, 1948, the appellant served a numberice the respondent before us who was a monthly tenant in occupation of Block No. B/2 the ground floor of the New Sitaram Building

facts.text: Appellant filed summary Suit No. 106 of 1948 in City Civil Court for possession and mesne profits from August 1, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant filed summary Suit No. 106 of 1948 against the respondent in the City Civil Court at Bombay for vacant possession of the said Block No. B/2

facts.text: City Civil Court decreed suit in favor of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The learned City Civil Court Judge in a well-considered and careful judgment answered the issues in favour of the appellant and decreed the suit.

facts.text: High Court reversed City Civil Court decision on ground of absence of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reversed the decision of the trial Judge and holding that the Bombay Act LVII of 1947 did apply to the premises and companysequently

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appeal after High Court declined certificate.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having declined to grant leave to the appellant to appeal to this Court, the appellant applied for and obtained special leave of this Court

facts.text: Respondent claimed protection of Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: By his advocates reply the respondent maintained that he had been paying the rent regularly and otherwise performing the terms of his tenancy and claimed the protection

facts.text: Building known as New Sitaram Building erected by Sitaram Luxman on the plots.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this agreement the said Sitaram Luxman erected those plots a building which has since companye to be known as the New Sitaram Building.

facts.text: Premises belong to local authority (Bombay Municipality).

anchor.surface_text: In our view in the case before us the demised premises including the building belong to a local authority and are outside the operation of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: section 4 (1) of the Bombay Act LVII of 1947, Which runs as follows- 4. anchor.surface_text: namely, 1 whether the Court had jurisdiction and 2 whether the Bombay Act LVII of 1947 applied to the premises in suit. The learned City Civil Court Judge in a well-considered and careful judgment answered the issues in favour of the appellant and decreed the suit.

issues.text: whether the Bombay Act LVII of 1947 applied to the premises in suit

anchor.surface_text: and 2 whether the Bombay Act LVII of 1947 applied to the premises in suit. The learned City Civil Court Judge in a well-considered and careful judgment answered the issues in favour of the appellant and decreed the suit. The respondent appealed to the High Court.

issues.text: that the City Civil Court had no jurisdiction to entertain the suit

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent took a preliminary objection, founded the provisions of section 28 of the Bombay Act, that the City Civil Court had no jurisdiction to entertain the suit, for that section clearly states that in Greater Bombay the Court of Small Causes alone shall have jurisdiction to entertain and try any suit between a landlord and a tenant relating to the recovery of rent or possession of any premises to which any of the provisions of that Part of the Act applied

issues.text: who is to decide this point in controversy

anchor.surface_text: The question at once arises as to who is to decide this point in controversy. It is well settled that a Civil Court has inherent power to decide the question of its own jurisdiction, although, as a result of its enquiry, it may turn out that it has no jurisdiction over the suit.

issues.text: whether the Act applies to the demised premises

anchor.surface_text: The main controversy between the parties is as to whether the Act applies to the demised premises. The solution of that controversy depends upon a true construction of section 4 (1) of the Bombay Act LVII of 1947, Which runs as follows- 4. (1) This Act shall not apply to any premises belonging to the Government or a local authority or apply as against the Government to any tenancy or other like relationship created by a grant from the Government in respect of premises,

issues.text: the crucial point... is to ascertain whether, in view of section 4 of the Act, the Act applies to the premises at all

anchor.surface_text: The crucial point, therefore, in order to determine the question of the jurisdiction of the City Civil Court to entertain the suit, is to ascertain whether, in view of section 4 of the Act, the Act applies to the premises at all. If it does, the City Civil Court has no jurisdiction but if it does not, then it has such jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 105 of the Transfer of Property Act a lease is a transfer only of a right to enjoy the demised, premises... In our view in the case before us

holdings.text: A Civil Court has inherent power to decide the question of its own jurisdiction, although as a result of its enquiry it may turn out that it has no jurisdiction over the suit.

anchor.surface_text: It is well settled that a Civil Court has inherent power to decide the question of its own jurisdiction, although, as a result of its enquiry, it may turn out that it has no jurisdiction over the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled principle; court must determine applicability of jurisdictional bar before declining jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The preliminary objection that the City Civil Court had no jurisdiction under section 28 of the Bombay Rents Act is not well founded and should be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we think, in agreement with the High Court, that this preliminary objection is not well founded in principle or authority and should be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction turns on whether Act applies per s.4; civil court empowered to decide that threshold issue.

holdings.text: Section 4(1) of the Bombay Rents Act has three distinct parts; the first part exempts premises belonging to the Government or a local authority entirely from the operation of the Act, conferring immunity on the premises themselves.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that the above sub-section has three parts, namely- This Act shall not apply to premises belonging to the Government or a local authority, This Act shall not apply as against the Government to any tenancy or other like relationship created by grant from the Government in respect of premises,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis distinguishes first part (no mention of 'tenancy') from second; deliberate legislative choice for broader exemption.

holdings.text: The exemption under the first part of section 4(1) attaches to the premises and is available not only to the Government or local authority but also to lessees deriving title therefrom.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion is, therefore, irresistible that the Legislature did not by the first part intend to exempt the relationship of landlord and tenant but intended to confer the premises belonging to Government an immunity from the operation of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of 'as against the Government/local authority' phrasing unlike second part; protects reversionary interests and enables building leases without subletting restrictions.

holdings.text: The demised premises, including the building erected by the lessee, belong to the local authority (Bombay Municipality) and are outside the operation of the Bombay Rents Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our view in the case before us the demised premises including the building belong to a local authority and are outside the operation of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lease transfers enjoyment right only (s.105 TPA), not ownership; covenants show lessor dominance; building fixtures part of land per agreement (s.108 TPA).

anchor.surface_text: Further, as pointed out by Romer L. J. in Clark v. Downes 1 , which case was approved by Lord Goddard C.J. in Rudler v. Franks 1  such immunity will increase the value of the right of reversion belonging to the Government or a local authority.

precedents.cited_proposition: such immunity will increase the value of the right of reversion belonging to the Government or a local authority

anchor.surface_text: Further, as pointed out by Romer L. J. in Clark v. Downes 1 , which case was approved by Lord Goddard C.J. in Rudler v. Franks 1  such immunity will increase the value of the right of reversion belonging to the Government or a local authority.

precedents.cited_proposition: approval of the view that such immunity will increase the value of the right of reversion belonging to the Government or a local authority

anchor.surface_text: Said Lord Macnaghten in Heritable Reversionary Company v. Mullar 1 --  I   1892 A.C. 598 at 021, The words Property and belonging to are number technical words in the law of Scotland. They are to be understood, I think, in their ordinary signification. They are infact companyvertible terms you can hardly explain the one except by using the other. A mans property is that which is his own, that which belongs to him. What belongs to him is his pro- perty.

precedents.cited_proposition: The words 'Property' and 'belonging to' are not technical words and are to be understood in their ordinary signification; they are convertible terms
precedents.cited_holding: The words Property and belonging to are number technical words in the law of Scotland. They are to be understood, I think, in their ordinary signification. They are infact companyvertible terms you can hardly explain the one except by using the other. A mans property is that which is his own, that which belongs to him. What belongs to him is his pro- perty.
